data.text: Merino Wool is Expensive. Any Alternatives?
Merino wool is damned expensive. Anyone have a line on a more budget-friendly brand?
If it is budget friendly, it 9.9/10 times not 100% merino but mixed. And that defeats the purpose of Merino. Better save up and invest, you won't regret.
data.author: Axel Knobbe

data.text: Agreed, but otherwise check Decathlon :-)
data.author: Marloes Demmendaal

data.text: yea, Decathlon has some nice merino stuff. Not 100% merino... Think it's about 85%. Went 5 days without my short smelling, which is pretty good üëå
data.author: Ray D. Chaplin

data.text: vote from me for Decathlon as well. Good for all weather conditions and yes the big advantage - it doesn't start smelling very ugly after one or two days like synthetics.
data.author: Markus Eichelberg

data.text: Similarly with buying Gortex for true rain proofing, an expensive outlay but you don't regret it, same with Merino's performance.

data.text: even the cheapest Merino is astoundingly different and better than anything else I have tried. You buy it once.
data.author: Shari Vari

data.text: Interestingly it dates from Spain in the middle ages & was illegal to export, if so, possible death sentence.

data.text: I‚Äôve seen items with tiny amounts of Merino, probably just enough to be able to legally use Merino in the labelling: those might have spotty performance . But any high percentage Merino product I‚Äôve experienced has been worth it. I‚Äôm sorry you aren‚Äôt also seeing the benefits .
data.author: David Muise

data.text: Smartwool is my goto. They have 100% and various blends.
data.author: Shawn Holiday

data.text: merino wool never proved itself to me. almost 5 year bicycle touring and over 20 years as a professional snowboard instructor trainer, backcountry guide, and head coach of a competitive team - all the free smartwool 100% merino swag I got was nice but I feel no difference. I still wear good old cheap Walmart thermals in winter season. When I cycle the other 7 months, I use quick dry polyester shirts I got from REI years ago. They last longer too. I also find the merino wool after 1-2 day of cycling, get real itchy with all the sweat salt that gets trapped in it unlike polyester shirts that remove it to the outside of the shirt - and can be quickly washed off at night and dried by morning - I can wear for a few days before they are stinky - doesn't bother me, I change for those around me :)
data.author: Adir Sharon

data.text: My favorite "wool" jacket is a 20 years old North Face fleece. Easy to wash and undestructible. I've always been a fan of wool and cherish still my old handmade sweaters my mother knitted. But they are heavy and difficult to wash and dry.
data.author: J√∂rg Duurkoop

data.text: my thoughts exactly.
data.author: Robert Duggan

data.text: I have to say I prefer cotton, never smells, I end up using it under my base layers as it stops them smelling so I can get more that a days snowboarding out of them. I've tried Merino but it just isn't as comfortable as a 100% cotton t-shirt
data.author: Gregory Arthur Brett

data.text: Merino wool isnt a brand its a type a wool from a special race of sheep there is no cheap way around it
data.author: Menno Pieters

data.text: yes, I know it‚Äôs not a brand, I was just wondering if some brand actually sold merino wool products that were cheaper. It sounds like the answer is no.
data.author: Tony De Jesus

data.text: no most are blends now anyway you can look into ratios of the blend and see what you like the best for me its at least 63% merino and 17%spandex
data.author: Menno Pieters

data.text: Decathlon do a good range at a reasonable price. Not all of the products are 100% but I've found them a good compromise: low odour and in temperatures down to -5c reasonably thermally efficient
data.author: Graeme Thomson

data.text: I have a merino gravel cycling Jersey and its brilliant. Well worth it
data.author: Sam Minett-Smith

data.text: Merino, as others already mentioned a special sheep that‚Äôs has a special fine fibre that‚Äôs not itch. Really cheap products of merino could be from range that are known for animal cruelty. But not always of course. It‚Äôs important to check labels etc. Some people are very sensitive to wool even it‚Äôs fine fibres but if not it‚Äôs a good product. Synthetic fibres can never replace wool.
data.author: Ingela Wahlberg

data.text: yes, I would strongly prefer a brand that isn‚Äôt inhumane.

data.text: Charity shop lambswool or Shetland wool.

data.text: Shop around for discounts. It's a fantastic product and like with everything else you get what you pay for (but you can find good deals occasionally, for instance at the end of holiday seasons).

data.text: In time the lanolin needs replaced, just pop open a few vitamin D capsules and rub it into your merino.

data.text: Try the Decathlon merino wool products.

data.text: These are not 100% wool, but 100% is not hard wearing. A wool synthetic blend is more practical. I have their 180 base layer that I use a lot.

data.text: same. Got a variety of stuff from them and it works well.
data.author: Ray D. Chaplin

data.text: Cheap merino = short fibers and less sturdy. There will be holes.
data.author: Mats Aadde

data.text: There are different prices/ brands/ qualities even of 100 per cent merino (or merino silk blends which I prefer) And Merino is not just one quality, Merino fibers comes in various qualities, from the very finest and most expensive fibers which is close to the fine fibers of cashmere up to the more coarse and (sturdier) fibers which resemble more normal wool types.
data.author: Kjell Hamran Vegge √òdeg√•rd

data.text: I've found icebreaker on special discount on amazon UK occasionally. I bought my rohan 200 weight merino on sale from their UK stores. I bought one set of icebreaker merinos from their factory store in Auckland NZ near the airport.

data.text: It pays itself back one thousand times! I walked the Camino del norte with only 2 merino wool T-shirts. One for the day and the dry and clean one during evenings and night. The walking T-shirt hanging to dry over night. In the morning it was fresh. I washed it every 4 days only. That's all you will ever need! My friend had also knickers and bra of wool. We have both super delicate skin. The best option ever. Nowadays I even have jogging pants of wool. And I am an elegant lady üòâ

data.text: In the UK there's a brand called Endura that I have several base layers, both long and short sleeve, from, and they've all worn well (apart from one t shirt I managed to snag on something nasty). I've even found a merino top at a bargain supermarket called Aldi. I wear them a lot both on and off the bike - they make fab base layers for ordinary life too!

data.text: Cashmere - gotta have the right tools
data.author: Sally Riccio Spencer

data.text: I‚Äôve found 100% merino to be notably better than the blends I have. I buy through Sierra trading post and REI end of season (around February) for deep discounts. I‚Äôve also found some deals on Amazon in February as well. Helly Hansen was 50% off for healthcare workers during one year of Covid. Now the discount is less (20%??), but still present. Happy bargain hunting!
data.author: Sarah Slowik

data.text: I'm so convinced that Merinno wool is the best all-around clothing, I have three long sleeved shirts. One I've had for ten years and despite having several holes, it's a functional outdoor work shirt. It's "replacement," bought about five years ago, shows no sign of wear, though worn daily on bicycle tours or rides in cooler weather. For safe measure I acquired a hooded one for really terrible days. Seems I'm covered for yesterday, today, and tomorrow. Not bragging, but just a true believer. These three will probably outlast me.
data.author: Bill Bacon

data.text: I felt the same but bought an Icebreaker t shirt recently for a 10 day walk over 195 miles. OMG it was fantastic- wore it constantly in hot sweaty and cold rainy weather and it‚Äôs as if it‚Äôs brand new -with no washing! It will last me many many years, so the ‚Äòcost per wear‚Äô is minuscule. I vote for the investment. üòä

data.text: I don‚Äôt think I‚Äôve cycled a single kilometer on any trip without wearing at least one piece of merino. I like t-shirts with a mix of synthetic and merino for summer and long sleeve for other seasons. I have currently cycled around 10.000 km in the same t-shirt and small holes just started to show up lately. My long sleeves were bought in 2015 and are still fine. Just buy it‚Ä¶ Clothing is in constant contact with your body. I would rather safe money elsewhere.

data.text: Take the hit. I use RAB MOCO a combination of Merino wool and coconut husk. Can were all week without smelling, easy to wash and dry and RAB have a lifetime gt against defects. Just don't wash in detergent. I use pure soap liquid.
